input:
2. A 68-year-old male with a history of polymyalgia rheumatica presents with acute vision loss in his left eye that began abruptly two days ago. He describes a dull, throbbing pain around his temples and reports recently experiencing difficulty swallowing and occasional low-grade fevers. On examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the left eye and decreased color vision. Fundoscopic exam reveals a pale, swollen optic nerve head with cotton wool spots. Laboratory tests demonstrate an elevated ESR of 85 mm/hr and CRP of 45 mg/L. The patient also notes stiffness and aching in his shoulders and hips over the previous month. Temporal artery palpation reveals tenderness and reduced pulsation on the left side. A temporal artery biopsy is scheduled to confirm suspected giant cell arteritis causing arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, and corticosteroid therapy is urgently started.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient might be feeling confused and worried, possibly overwhelmed by the symptoms and the sudden change in vision. They probably want to explain their experience but might struggle with clear details, emphasizing their discomfort and the severity of the symptoms.
ANSWER: Well, I guess I really didn’t think much of it at first, but then suddenly my eye went really blurry, and I started feeling this dull ache around my head and temples, and it’s been bothering me pretty much all the time now. I’ve also been having a hard time swallowing and feeling kind of feverish off and on, but I don’t really know what’s going on.

input: 2. A 68-year-old male with a history of polymyalgia rheumatica presents with acute vision loss in his left eye that began abruptly two days ago. He describes a dull, throbbing pain around his temples and reports recently experiencing difficulty swallowing and occasional low-grade fevers. On examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the left eye and decreased color vision. Fundoscopic exam reveals a pale, swollen optic nerve head with cotton wool spots. Laboratory tests demonstrate an elevated ESR of 85 mm/hr and CRP of 45 mg/L. The patient also notes stiffness and aching in his shoulders and hips over the previous month. Temporal artery palpation reveals tenderness and reduced pulsation on the left side. A temporal artery biopsy is scheduled to confirm suspected giant cell arteritis causing arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, and corticosteroid therapy is urgently started.Can you tell me more about when your symptoms started, how they've changed over time, and if you've noticed anything that makes them better or worse?
output: Um, the vision thing just kind of came on all of a sudden, like one day I was fine and then suddenly I couldn’t see very well with that eye. The pain around my temples has been there off and on, and I feel like it’s worse when I try to move my head or if I stay in one position too long. I don’t think anything really makes it better, and it doesn’t seem to get better on its own, no.

input: 2. A 68-year-old male with a history of polymyalgia rheumatica presents with acute vision loss in his left eye that began abruptly two days ago. He describes a dull, throbbing pain around his temples and reports recently experiencing difficulty swallowing and occasional low-grade fevers. On examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the left eye and decreased color vision. Fundoscopic exam reveals a pale, swollen optic nerve head with cotton wool spots. Laboratory tests demonstrate an elevated ESR of 85 mm/hr and CRP of 45 mg/L. The patient also notes stiffness and aching in his shoulders and hips over the previous month. Temporal artery palpation reveals tenderness and reduced pulsation on the left side. A temporal artery biopsy is scheduled to confirm suspected giant cell arteritis causing arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, and corticosteroid therapy is urgently started.Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have been affecting your daily activities, and if you've noticed any other changes or symptoms that you've not yet mentioned?
output: Well, I guess it’s been kind of hard to do things like I used to. My vision problems make it hard to see clearly, and I feel a bit all over the place with my strength sometimes. I’ve also been feeling more tired than usual, and I think I’ve been a bit colder or maybe just achier overall. I just— I don’t know, everything’s been a bit confusing and it’s kinda scary not knowing what’s going on.

input: 2. A 68-year-old male with a history of polymyalgia rheumatica presents with acute vision loss in his left eye that began abruptly two days ago. He describes a dull, throbbing pain around his temples and reports recently experiencing difficulty swallowing and occasional low-grade fevers. On examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the left eye and decreased color vision. Fundoscopic exam reveals a pale, swollen optic nerve head with cotton wool spots. Laboratory tests demonstrate an elevated ESR of 85 mm/hr and CRP of 45 mg/L. The patient also notes stiffness and aching in his shoulders and hips over the previous month. Temporal artery palpation reveals tenderness and reduced pulsation on the left side. A temporal artery biopsy is scheduled to confirm suspected giant cell arteritis causing arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, and corticosteroid therapy is urgently started.Can you tell me more about how your symptoms started, how they have changed over time, and if you've noticed any additional symptoms or patterns that seem to come and go?
output: Well, it just sort of happened suddenly, like one day I was fine and then everything just looked kind of dim and blurry in that one eye. It’s been like that for a couple of days now, and I don’t really know why or if it’s gotten worse. I’ve also been feeling some pain around my head and temples, and I’ve been kinda tired and not myself, but I can’t figure out if that’s related or not.

A temporal artery biopsy is scheduled to confirm suspected giant cell arteritis causing arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, and corticosteroid therapy is urgently started.Have you noticed any recent infections, exposure to sick contacts, or symptoms like neck stiffness, rash, or sensitivity to light that might suggest an infectious or inflammatory process?
output: No, I don't think I've been around anyone sick or noticed anything like that. I just feel kind of tired and like my head is heavy sometimes, but I don’t really know if that counts.

input: 2. A 68-year-old male with a history of polymyalgia rheumatica presents with acute vision loss in his left eye that began abruptly two days ago. He describes a dull, throbbing pain around his temples and reports recently experiencing difficulty swallowing and occasional low-grade fevers. Temporal artery palpation reveals tenderness and reduced pulsation on the left side. A temporal artery biopsy is scheduled to confirm suspected giant cell arteritis causing arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, and corticosteroid therapy is urgently started.Have you experienced any recent headaches, neck stiffness, sensitivity to light or sound, or any skin rashes? Also, have you noticed any recent weight loss, night sweats, or any new neurological deficits such as weakness, numbness, or difficulty speaking?
output: Um, I’ve been having some aches around my shoulders and hips, and I guess I’ve felt a bit more tired than usual. No headaches or neck stiffness that I can think of, and I haven’t noticed any rashes or anything unusual on my skin. I haven’t really had any new weakness or speech problems, just these weird feelings in my eye and some discomfort around my temples.

Also, how old are you, and have you experienced any scalp tenderness or jaw claudication?
output: It's kinda hard to describe, but I think I’ve lost more in that eye, like parts of my vision are just gone or fuzzy now. The other eye feels alright for now, but the whole thing seemed worse at first. I’m 68 years old. Umm, my scalp’s been kinda sore, and sometimes I get pain when I chew or open my mouth wide.

input: 2. A 68-year-old male with a history of polymyalgia rheumatica presents with acute vision loss in his left eye that began abruptly two days ago. He describes a dull, throbbing pain around his temples and reports recently experiencing difficulty swallowing and occasional low-grade fevers. On examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect in the left eye and decreased color vision. Fundoscopic exam reveals a pale, swollen optic nerve head with cotton wool spots. Laboratory tests demonstrate an elevated ESR of 85 mm/hr and CRP of 45 mg/L. The patient also notes stiffness and aching in his shoulders and hips over the previous month. Temporal artery palpation reveals tenderness and reduced pulsation on the left side. A temporal artery biopsy is scheduled to confirm suspected giant cell arteritis causing arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, and corticosteroid therapy is urgently started.Are you experiencing any new or worsening symptoms, such as increased vision loss, new jaw pain when chewing, or new headaches, that might indicate progression of the inflammation and necessitate immediate treatment?
output: Well, I do feel like... maybe my vision is kind of worse, or at least it feels different today. My jaw doesn’t really hurt when I chew, but sometimes I get a weird ache in my head, especially on the side that's affected. I’m not sure if it’s getting more or different, but I just feel like things are not the same as before.
